question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Solve the inequality
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| < 5.\]
inference:
We split this into cases.

Case 1: $x \le -2.$  Then
\[-(x - 1) - (x + 2) < 5,\]so $-2x - 1 < 5,$ which means $x > -3.$  Hence, the solutions in this case are $-3 < x \le -2.$

Case 2: $-2 \le x \le 1.$  Then
\[-(x - 1) + (x + 2) < 5,\]so $3 < 5,$ which is always true.  Hence, the solutions in this case are $-2 \le x \le 1.$

Case 3: $x \ge 1.$  Then
\[(x - 1) + (x + 2) < 5,\]so $2x + 1 < 5,$ which means $x < 2.$  Hence, the solutions in this case are $1 \le x < 2.$

Combining all the cases, the solutions are $\boxed{-3 < x < 2}.$
ground_truth:
If $x < -2,$ then
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| = -(x - 1) - (x + 2) = -2x - 1.\]Solving $-2x - 1 < 5,$ we get $x > -3.$  So, the values of $x$ that work in this case are $-3 < x < -2.$

If $-2 \le x < 1,$ then
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| = -(x - 1) + (x + 2) = 3.\]All values in $-2 \le x < 1$ work.

If $1 \le x,$ then
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| = (x - 1) + (x + 2) = 2x + 1.\]Solving $2x + 1 < 5,$ we get $x < 2.$  So the values of $x$ that work in this case are $1 \le x < 2.$

Therefore, the solution is $x \in \boxed{(-3,2)}.$
